isis.stitle: ELECTRICAL SYSTEM TROUBLESHOOTING GUIDE - 3200, 4200, 4300, 4400, 7300, 7400, 7500, 8500, 8600 - ELECTRICAL SYSTEM TROUBLESHOOTING GUIDE - 3000FE, 3000RE - 3000FE BATTERY, CHARGING AND CRANKING SYSTEMS - TROUBLESHOOTING

svcprocinfo.para: Before beginning these test procedures, do the following:

item.para: Make sure the vehicle batteries are at 75% state of charge (SOC) or higher. This represents an open circuit voltage (OCV) of 12.4 volts. Batteries with an OCV of 12 volts or less are either completely discharged or have a dead cell.
Check any light or indicator lamp filaments that are suspected of being open (burned out). This is done to avoid unnecessary extensive circuit checks.
Inspect all connectors for loose or damaged pins, wires, etc. Refer to TEST EQUIPMENT AND CONNECTOR REPAIR section in GROUP 08 - ELECTRICAL in the CTS-5000 Master Service Manual.

When the technician determines that a fuse is blown, while checking its condition, he is directed to locate the cause of the overload condition and to repair it. While no further instruction on this procedure is listed in the diagnostic tables, the common procedure is as follows: isolate sections of the circuit by disconnecting connectors, and measure the resistance to ground to find the circuit that is shorted to ground. Then locate the damaged spot in the wire or connector and repair.

Diagnostics for circuits that are malfunctioning by sticking in the on position are generally not covered in detail. It is assumed that the technician knows to check for a malfunctioning switch, relay, or solenoid.

svcsubproc.title: Batteries and Cables
svcsubproc.para: The standard battery system for the 3000RE consists of two 12V maintenance-free batteries.

warning.para: When handling batteries, always wear face or eye protection, have water supply available, assure good ventilations, and be sure no open flames are present.

svcsubproc.title: Batteries and Cables - Battery Test Procedure (Figure 53)
svcsubproc.para: Test each battery separately.

step1.para: Disconnect both battery terminals at each battery. Check each battery visually.
Examine the hydrometer eye (if no eye go to next step).

step2.para: Eye shows green - go to step 4.
Eye shows dark - recharge, then go to step 3.

step1.para: Apply a 300A load for 15 seconds. Turn off load and wait one minute.

step2.para: If 12.4V or more - go to step 4.
If less than 12.4V - recharge, then repeat step 3.

step1.para: Apply a test load equal to 50% of the battery CCA rating at 0°F. After 15 seconds, with the load still applied, read and record terminal voltage __________. Turn the load off.
Estimate the battery temperature. If measured voltage does not meet or exceed the value shown in the following table, replace the battery.
Clean all cable ends and terminals of the battery with a wire brush.

svcsubproc.title: Batteries and Cables - Battery Cable Voltage Loss Test ( Figure 54).
svcsubproc.para: Slow cranking is often caused by high resistance in the battery cables or connections, especially in cold weather. After all batteries check good ( Battery Test Procedure) and terminals are clean and tight, check the battery cables. To do this, place a specific load on the batteries at the starter and measure the voltage drop in each cable. This load will be supplied by the adjustable carbon pile.

The voltage drop in the positive cable plus the voltage drop in the negative cable equals the difference between the battery voltage and the starter voltage due to the cables. The maximum acceptable loss has been calculated only for the specific load specified in the test.

step1.para: Tighten nuts holding battery cables to the solenoid and starter terminals.

note.para: The solenoid BAT terminal is at battery voltage when batteries are connected.

step1.para: Connect carbon pile positive lead to starter solenoid BAT terminal and negative lead to starter ground terminal.
Connect voltmeter from the starter solenoid "B" terminal to battery positive post.
Turn carbon pile on and adjust load to 500A. Read and record positive cable voltage drop. Turn off the load and allow carbon pile to cool.
Connect voltmeter from negative battery post to starter ground terminal. Attach leads directly to ground studs and not the cables.
Turn carbon pile on and adjust load to 500A. Read and record negative cable voltage drop. Turn off the load.

svcsubproc.para: POSITIVE CABLE Voltage Loss (step 4) __________
NEGATIVE CABLE Voltage Loss (step 6) __________
TOTAL CABLE LOSS__________
If system loss is 0.6V or less, go to Starting Motor System Circuits and Components.
If total cable loss is greater than 0.6V, repair or replace cable(s) with excessive voltage loss and retest.

svcsubproc.title: Starting Motor System Circuits and Components
svcsubproc.para: This section consists of five parts: Starter Solenoid Circuit Test - Part 1, Starter Solenoid Circuit Test - Part 2, Engine Cranking System Circuit Test, Testing Thermal Overcrank Protection System, and Starter Motor Replacement Test.

svcsubproc.title: Starter Solenoid Circuit Test - Part 1 ( Figure 55)
svcsubproc.para: Starter shifting in and out, or not pulling in, is often caused by high resistance in the starter solenoid circuit. When the solenoid circuit has excessive voltage loss, the starter pinion sometimes may not engage the flywheel. If it does engage, it may drop out too soon when battery voltage drops. The solenoid circuit includes the starter relay switch (located front side of platform) and leads connected to the starter solenoid.
On vehicles with overcrank protection, refer to Testing Thermal Overcrank Protection System before performing this test.

step1.para: Disconnect starter relay circuit 17C from the starter solenoid "S" terminal.

Connect the carbon pile positive lead to circuit 17C and the negative lead to the starter ground. Connect the positive lead of a DMM voltmeter to the solenoid "B" terminal. Connect negative lead of voltmeter to switch wire lead 17C (not to carbon pile clamp). Meter will show battery voltage.

Have an assistant turn the key switch to the start position. Voltmeter reading should be zero. You should hear the starter relay switch energize with a clicking sound. If the switch doesn't "click," either the starter relay switch is defective or there is no voltage from the key switch circuit (refer to diagnostic test, Engine Cranking System Circuit Test).

Turn on and adjust the carbon pile to 50 amp load (for no more than 10 seconds). Read and record __________ voltage on voltmeter. Release the key start switch. Turn off and disconnect carbon pile and voltmeter.

svcsubproc.para: If circuit loss is 0.5 volt or less, solenoid circuitry is OK. Go to Engine Cranking System Circuit Test.
If circuit loss is more than 0.5 volt, go to Starter Solenoid Circuit Test - Part 2.

svcsubproc.title: Starter Solenoid Circuit Test - Part 2 (Figure 56)
svcsubproc.para: If voltage loss in Starter Solenoid Circuit Test - Part 1 was more than 0.5 volt, the loss is excessive. The loss may be from loose terminals, corrosion, or a worn out starter relay switch. To locate the problem:

step1.para: Disconnect circuit 17C from "S" terminal at starter solenoid. Connect carbon pile to circuit 17C and to starter ground terminal. Turn the carbon pile on (will show 0 amps).
Disconnect starter relay and install a jumper lead from cavity 4, circuit 17C to cavity 1, circuit 17B.

note.para: Test lead will be at battery voltage.

step1.para: Connect DMM from solenoid BAT terminal to start relay connector cavity 1, circuit 17B (will show zero volts).

At relay connector, install other end of jumper lead to cavity 4, circuit 17C. Turn on and adjust carbon pile to 50 amp load (no more than 10 seconds). Read and record first wire voltage loss. Disconnect DMM.
At relay connector, connect DMM from cavity 4, 17C to circuit 17C at carbon pile. Connect to terminal and not to carbon pile clamp.
Turn on and adjust carbon pile to 50 amp load (no more than 10 seconds). Read and record second wire voltage loss. Disconnect and remove jumper lead and DMM.

svcsubproc.para: First Wire Loss (step 3) __________
Second Wire loss (step 5) __________
Total Wiring Loss = __________(0.4V maximum loss)
If wiring loss is 0.4 volt or less, replace starter relay and retest per Starter Solenoid Circuit Test - Part 1.
If wiring loss is more than 0.4 volt, repair or replace wire(s), and retest per Starter Solenoid Circuit Test - Part 1.
If retest results are still above 0.5 volt loss, replace starter relay and retest per Starter Solenoid Circuit Test - Part 1.

note.para: Perform Starter Solenoid Circuit Test - Part 1 and Part 2 before conducting the following test.

entry.para: Using suitable jumper wire, jump crank motor solenoid "B" terminal to "S" terminal. Does crank motor operate?
Go to Starter Motor Replace- ment Test.
Remove crank relay (385). With transmission in neutral, measure voltage from circuit 97L to ground.
Install relay (385). Go to next step.
Go to Step 17 for diagnostics of the ignition relay and neutral position switch circuitry.
Remove start relay (387). At connector, measure voltage from circuit 17A to ground.
At connector (387), measure voltage from circuit 17B to ground.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit 17-FL/ 17B, then repair.
At connector (387), measure voltage across circuit 17B to circuit 17C.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit 17C, then repair.
At connector (387), measure voltage across circuit 17B to circuit 17D.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit 17D or 17-G/ 11-GJ, then repair. Also test Thermal Overcrank Protection Switch.
Reconnect start relay (387). Disconnect dash connector (2). Measure voltage from circuit 17 to ground.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in front key switch (20), circuit 17A, start interrupt conn. (195) or circuit 17, then repair.
Reconnect connector (2) and disconnect engine harness from control box connector (3). At harness, measure voltage from circuit 17 to ground.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit 17, chassis/ engine harness conn. (196), or circuit 17, then repair.
At harness connector (3), measure voltage from circuit 14B to ground.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit 14B/ 14B-FL, then repair.
Reconnect connector (3) and disconnect crank relay (385). With front key switch in start position, measure voltage from circuit 17/17E to ground.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit 17/ 17E or front/ rear switch (618), then repair.
With rear key switch in start position, measure voltage from circuit 17BB/17E to ground.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit 17BB/17E, front/rear switch (618), rear key switch (20), circuit 14/14B, then repair.
At connector (385), measure voltage from circuit 97L to circuit 17A.
Locate open or poor connection in circuit 17A, control box conn. (3) or circuit 17A to start relay, then repair.
Disconnect ECM connector (379) and measure voltage from circuit 97A to ground.
Locate open or poor connection in circuit 97A, control box conn. (3) or circuit 97A, then repair.
At connector (379), connect jumper wire from circuit 97A to circuit 97H. At crank relay (385), measure voltage from circuit 97H to ground.
Locate open or poor connection in circuit 97H, control box conn. (3) or circuit 97H, then repair.
Remove jumper and reconnect ECM (379). At crank relay (385), measure voltage from circuit 97H to ground.
Refer to Electronic Control System Diagnostics in the Engine Diagnostics Manual.
Reconnect crank relay (385). Does crank motor operate?
Engine starting system circuits check good.
At rear fuse holder (1B), check fuse B2 for open condition.
Locate cause of overload condition and repair. Replace fuse.
At rear fuse holder (1B), measure voltage from circuit 13P to ground.
Disconnect dash connector (2) and measure voltage from circuit 13K to ground.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in front key switch (20), circuit 13/13A, fuse F19, or circuit 13K, then repair.
Reconnect connector (2) and disconnect engine harness from control box connector (3). At harness, measure voltage from circuit 13K to ground.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit 13K, chassis/ engine harness connector (196), or circuit 13K, then repair.
At harness connector (3), measure voltage from circuit 14B to ground.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit 14B/ 14B-FL, then repair.
Reconnect engine harness to connector (3). Inside control box, remove blocking diode assembly (47). With multimeter in diode test mode, test diode.
With front key switch in the on or start position, and at diode connector (47), measure voltage from circuit 13K to ground.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit 13K, then repair.
With rear key switch in the on or start position, and at diode connector (47), measure voltage from circuit 13N to ground.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit 14/14B, key switch (20), or circuit 13N, then repair.
Install diode assembly (47) and disconnect ignition relay connector (458). At connector, measure voltage from circuit 13R to ground.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit 13R, then repair.
At connector (458), measure voltage from circuit 13R to circuit 11-G.
Locate open or poor connection in circuit 11-G, then repair.
Disconnect engine stop switch connector (187). Measure voltage from circuit 14A to ground.
Locate open or poor connection in circuit 14A, then repair.
At engine stop switch (187), measure resistance across terminals.
Reconnect (187) and at ignition relay connector (458), measure voltage from circuit 14D to ground.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit 14D, then repair.
Bench test relay (458) by applying +12V to pin 85 and ground to pin 86. Measure resistance across pin 30 to 87.
Install relay (458). Go to next step.
At rear fuse holder (1B) fuse B2, measure voltage from circuit 13P to ground.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit 13P, then repair.
Disconnect neutral position switch connectors (N/L). Measure voltage from circuit 97P to ground.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit 97P, control box conn. (3), or 97P, then repair.
At neutral position switch (N/L) and with transmission in neutral, measure resistance across terminals.
Reconnect neutral position switch connectors and remove crank relay (385). Measure voltage from circuit 97L to ground.
Locate cause of low or no voltage in circuit 97L, then repair.
Reconnect crank relay (385). Engine start system circuitry checks good.
Remove connector (N/L) from thermal switch and measure resistance across switch terminals (starter motor must not be hot).
With key in start position, at connector (N/L) measure voltage to ground at circuit 17D.
Go to Starter Solenoid Circuit Test - Part 1.
With key in start position, at connector (N/L) measure voltage between circuits 17D and 17-G.
Repair open in circuit 17G or 11-GJ to cranking motor ground stud.

svcsubproc.title: Starter Motor Replacement Test ( Figure 57)
svcsubproc.para: A. COLD WEATHER STARTER RELAY SWITCH PROBLEMS
If all tests from Battery Test Procedure through Testing Thermal Overcrank Protection System have been performed, the vehicle batteries and starter wiring have been checked.

The starter relay switch can fail to "hold in" during cold weather cranking due to low voltage, even though the switches and circuits check OK. This failure sounds as though the starter is failing to stay engaged to the flywheel. It is caused by low system voltage releasing the starter relay switch.

If this condition exists, remove starter relay switch. At the connector, using suitable jumper wire, attach one lead to circuit 17B and the other to circuit 17C. NOTE: Circuit 17B is at battery voltage and the engine should crank when the other end of the jumper is connected to circuit 17C. Remove jumper to stop cranking.
If engine cranks properly with jumper in place, replace starter relay switch and make sure starter mounting bolts are tight.
B. CHECKING AVAILABLE VOLTAGE AT STARTER
If all previous tests have been performed, the vehicle batteries and starter wiring have been checked. If the engine still cranks slowly, check available voltage at the starter.

step1.para: While cranking engine, measure voltage between the starter "BAT" terminal and starter ground.

step2.para: If voltage is 9.0 volts or more, the problem must be in the starter (or engine). Replace the starter.
If the voltage is less than 9.0 volts, go to step 2.

step1.para: Check the interconnecting cable between the batteries. While cranking, measure the terminal voltage of each battery by touching voltmeter leads to the post of each battery.

step2.para: If the difference between any two battery readings in the same battery box is more than 0.5 volt or any cable is warm to the touch, replace the interconnecting cables.
If cables check OK, the problem must be in the starter (or engine). Replace the starter.

svcsubproc.title: Vehicle Charging System
svcsubproc.para: This section consists of four parts: Batteries Undercharged, Alternator Tests, Alternator Wiring Test, and Alternator Replacement Test.

svcsubproc.title: Batteries Undercharged
svcsubproc.para: Before beginning test procedures: check battery cables and alternator wiring (especially grounds) for clean, tight connections. Wires and connectors should not be damaged or corroded.
Perform the following checks before removing the alternator from the vehicle.

step1.para: Accessories having been left on for an extended time.

Check alternator drive belt tension (refer to GROUP 12 - ENGINE, Cooling in the CTS-5000 Master Service Manual for belt tension specifications). As a general rule, if the alternator fan can be rotated by pulling on the fan with one finger, the belt is too loose.
Inspect for defective batteries as described in GROUP 08 - ELECTRICAL, Battery Section in the CTS-5000 Master Service Manual.
Wiring defects. Visually check wiring, clamps and connections for clean, tight connections, free of damage and corrosion.
With the engine off, check voltage to ground at the (+) terminal of the alternator. A zero reading indicates an open in circuits 2, 2-FL, or 2A-FL between the alternator and batteries.
A defective component or wiring defect may be causing a small current drain that is less than the fuse rating for the circuit so the fuse does not open. To locate the unwanted current drain:

note.para: Batteries should be fully charged for the following test.

step2.para: KEY OFF - turn all accessories and controls off. Disconnect circuit 2 from the alternator B terminal.

To check entire system for current drains, insert DMM leads in the COM and 10A fused jack on the meter. Set the meter to DC Amps. Connect meter in series with the alternator. If meter leads are not connected with correct polarity, a (-) amp reading will be present.
Some current draw will be present. If the current draw is less than 0.3A move the lead from the 10A jack to the 320mA jack to read the exact current flow.

Refer to the Battery Power Distribution circuit diagrams in CTS-5216V. Remove the battery feed fuses one at a time, while monitoring the meter for any change in current flow. Note that some circuits (such as clock or radio or engine computer, etc.) should be drawing some current. Look for current draw in circuits that should not be active.

svcsubproc.title: Alternator Tests
svcsubproc.para: The alternator output must reach the batteries and accessory loads with a minimum amount of voltage loss. Any loss slows the rate of charge to the batteries and can cause the batteries to be undercharged. Discharged batteries can damage the starter and cause vehicle electrical components to operate improperly.

svcsubproc.title: Alternator Wiring Test (Figure 58)
svcsubproc.para: Instead of using alternator current output this test uses the same amount of current but draws it from the batteries (must be fully charged). Using the carbon pile load, the current flows in reverse through the circuit without the engine running.

step1.para: Connect the carbon pile to the alternator output terminal and to ground. Connect Fluke 88 DMM from alternator (+) terminal to positive battery terminal.
Turn on and adjust carbon pile to alternator rated output (amps). Read and record positive circuit voltage loss. Turn carbon pile off.
Connect the DMM from the alternator ground to the battery negative terminal.
Turn on and adjust carbon pile to alternator rated output (amps). Read and record negative circuit voltage loss. Turn carbon pile off.

svcsubproc.para: Positive Circuit Loss (step 2) ___________
Negative Circuit Loss (step 4) __________
TOTAL SYSTEM LOSS __________
If system loss is 0.7V or less, go to Alternator Replacement Test.
If system loss is greater than 0.7V, repair circuit(s) with excessive voltage loss and retest. Then go to Alternator Replacement Test.

svcsubproc.title: Alternator Replacement Test (Figure 59)
svcsubproc.para: If the wiring tests have been performed (circuits OK), adjust alternator belt and tighten mounting bolts and ground connections. Batteries must be near full charge with more than 12.4 volts no load voltage.
Voltage Output Test - Refer to Figure 59

step1.para: With vehicle at shop temperature, connect voltmeter between alternator BAT (+) and GND (-) terminals.
With NO electrical loads turned on, start the engine. Fast idle until voltage stabilizes (does not increase) for 2 minutes.
Check and record alternator output voltage ________ V (should not exceed 15.5 volts).
If voltage reading is above 15.5V, replace the alternator.

svcsubproc.para: Amperage Output Test - Refer to Figure 59

item.para: With vehicle at shop temperature, connect carbon pile and clamp-on ammeter as shown. Clamp around all wires connected to alternator B+ output terminal. (To use an ammeter without an induction clamp, disconnect circuits from alternator B+ terminal. Connect meter shunt between alternator B+ terminal and all circuits previously removed.) CAUTION - Do not connect an ammeter without a high current shunt.
With NO electrical loads turned on, start the engine, and speed up and retain a high RPM.
Turn on and adjust carbon pile until ammeter reads its highest value and record _______A.
Turn off carbon pile and engine.

If reading is zero (no output), the rotor should be magnetized with the alternator hooked up normally. To do this, momentarily connect a jumper lead from the alternator BAT (+) terminal to the indicator "I" terminal. This will restore normal residual magnetism.
Repeat steps 2, 3, and 4. If output is still zero, replace alternator.

svcsubproc.para: Replace alternator if either of the following exists:

item.para: Output current is not within 10% of the alternator rated output stamped on the alternator.
